item.title: Report E-2023050687
item.description:
Report E-2023050687

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-23T12:17:07+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-05-10
  • City: ALBUQUERQUE
  • State: NM
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS, INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: ON May 10, 2023, six (6) bags of calcium peroxide (UN1457) were damaged during transit and released approximately 25-pounds of product to the trailer interior and pallet below. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Advanced Environmental Solutions (AES) to remediate the impacted surfaces. AES personnel swept up the pure product and placed it in its own 55-gallon poly drum. The crew also wiped down the impacted freight and rewrapped the product for further shipment. All UN1457-impacted material was placed in one (1) separate 55-gallon drum for disposal.

  • Incident Date: 2023-05-16
  • City: ALBUQUERQUE
  • State: NM
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Bucket was brought to QA by manager. Inspection found that the shipping label, secondary barcode and vision labels were all blacked out. Further inspection found that the lid of the bucket had a crack along at the center and the liquid was able to leak out if the bucket was moved around too much. DescribePack: The crack was at the center part of the lid. The crack is small in terms of width but is 3/4 of an inch long. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The bucket was placed up right and transported by a cage as to not have the bucket move around too much. Bucket was then placed on pallet grate to ensure liquid didn't spill onto floor during inspection, bucket then safely placed inside hazmat bin.

  • Carrier/Reporter: LANDSTAR INWAY, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On May 3, 2023, at 1954 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Mentmore, New Mexico regarding the release of approximately 1 gallon of DELTA-THERM™ AR 8501 Polyol (Chemical under pressure, n.o.s., UN3500, 2.2) from (1) 3500-gallon metal tank. The release was reportedly due to a loading strap striking the release valve. No drains or waterways were affected by the release. Contractors were dispatched to clean up the release using a pressure washer and the proper PPE. The released material impacted rinse water was containerized in (1) 55-gallon metal drum which was then taken offsite by contractors for proper disposal.

item.title: Report I-2023060002
item.description:
Report I-2023060002

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-23T12:17:07+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-04-11
  • City: Gallup
  • State: NM
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: RUST & SONS TRUCKING, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Rust and Sons driver entered New Mexico on eastbound I-40 near Gallup at 8:00 pm on April 11,2023. Upon entering scale area the driver was instructed to move to an inspection area to complete a Level 1 inspection. During the inspection an officer noted a strong odor coming from the trailer. The doors of the trailer were opened to reveal the odor and a suspicion that there was a material leak within the load. This was deemed a non-emergency event and the driver was instructed to detach the trail6r from the truck in a cordened off area as no leak was visible inside or outside of the trailer. On April 12, 2023 US Ecology was contacted to mobilize a team to inspect the load. Prior to their arrival a fire engine was on site conducting tests to determine if it was safe to enter the trailer. US Ecology arrived on scene around 4:00 pm that afternoon to determine the origin of the smell. No leak was discovered but the totes had vented due to bulging of the totes. The crew opened the caps and vented all totes on the trailer. This caused condensation on the top of the totes which was cleaned up and the used cleaning materials were put into a 55 gallon drum and added to the load. A manifest for this drum was created to accompany the load which was then re-directed to Rineco in Benton Ark. for final disposal. ,

item.title: Report I-2023050100
item.description:
Report I-2023050100

Identified by scraper @ 2023-06-23T12:17:07+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-04-10
  • City: Caprock
  • State: NM
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: COASTAL TRANSPORT CO., INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: The cargo tank motor vehicle(CTMV) was traveling on highway 380 near mile marker 200. The C ™ V experienced a tire blow out on axle four, passenger side tire. The driver was unable to stop safely as the one lane each direction roadway contained no improved or paved shoulder for emergency stops. The driver was forced to travel r approximately 1.5 miles at slow speed b6fore the driver could safety stdp at a roadside pull out. The skidding tire overheated and ignited with flames. After stopping, the driver used the on board fire extinguisher in attempt to extinguish the fire. The flames quickly grew and Ignlted the product hoses stowed on the equipment tray that is mounted on the passenger side, below the cargo compartments. The fire/heat quickly melted through the aluminum shell of the cargo compartments. As the compartment shells melted through, the flammable liquid ignited. The fire consumed the cargo tank motor vehicle(truck trader/semi-trailer) and product. The Caprock volunteer fire deparlment contained the blaze and allowed the product to be consumed by the fire. Approximately 150 gallons of diesel fuel remained in the bottom of the compartment shell after the fire was extingulshed. This product was picked up and disposed of by the local HM response vendor that was called to the scene. The vehicle wreckage was loaded onto a flatbed semi-trailer and carried away for disposal. The HM response vendor scraped and cleaned the pavement area.

Upon investigation, it was noted that the four bolts for the liquid line flange were less than tool-tight. The bolts were tool-tightened and the car was cleaned. No gasket was noted inside the liquid line cap either. The threads were taped and the cap was tool-tightened.

  • Description: On 12/07/2022 at approximately 0900, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 5269340 at the station location in Farmington, reporting an undeclared resin spill. The shipment was a fiberboard box, containing a can labeled resin as well as other nonhazardous items. The package emitted an odor during the loading process. Further research revealed that the resin labeled container leaked inside of the box. The package was not labeled in accordance with IATA Regulations. The shipment is being held, pending an FAA investigation.

ER personnel deployed absorbents and worked them in with hand tools to remediate the impacted surface, then containerized all spent-absorbents into one (1) 30-gallon drum for disposal.

  • Description: This package was found to be leaking during the sort. It was a white outer bag, a plastic box was one layer down with two inner plastic cannisters. The plastic cannisters were not opened so there may have been inner receptacles inside them. There may have been urine samples in the package. Standard spill cleanup procedures were followed and the package was contained in a 1A2 steel salvage drum pending final disposition. Since the contents were UN 3373, Biological Substance Category B from the package markings, the National Response Center was notified by phone. NRC report # is 1344687.

  • Description: NM State Hazmat Inspector identified CELX 23213 as leaking while in the Clovis yard. The car was isolated and BNSF Hazmat responder inspected the car finding a small leak coming from the liquid line flange below the valve. 2 of 4 bolts were loose and tightened approximately 1 full turn each to stop the leak. Hazmat Hold placed on the car and shipper notified to request OTMA 1 for movement to destination for offloading and shop for repair/testing. All spilled material evaporated from the car body with no ground impacts.

  • Description: SHPX 207609 was found in Rincon, NM to be actively leaking front the top of the car. Upon inspection, it was noted that the liquid line was leaking from the cap. The cap was found to be tool tight, but no thread sealant was found on the threads. Responder vented car by opening vent, removed the cap, applied thread sealant and secured the cap, tool tight. Car was cleaned as well as soil remediated and released.
